title: Boris to ask for extension if no deal is reached in next two weeks
text:
Boris Johnson could have to ask the EU for an extension (Picture: Getty)

Boris Johnson will ask for a Brexit extension if he has not reached a deal by October 19, a court has been told.

Government documents say the Prime Minister accepts he has to ask Brussels for a delay – which is in direct contradiction to what he has said in public.

The revelations were made in Scottish court papers as part of a hearing designed to ensure Mr Johnson does not allow us to crash out of the EU in a ‘damaging no-deal Brexit’ at the end of the month.

Opponents of a no-deal Brexit went to the Court of Session in Edinburgh in a bid to ‘remind Boris Johnson that he is not above the law.’

The Government is saying that it will send the Benn Act letter and it will not frustrate the Act (i.e. by seeking to persuade a r27 Member State to veto our request for an extension). So what is left of the Prime Minister's promise that we will leave on 31.10? https://t.co/gsJIMEUkV3 — Jo Maugham QC (@JolyonMaugham) October 4, 2019

They wanted clarification that he would follow the Benn Act – the legislation passed by rebel Tories and opposition groups that would make no-deal illegal.

The new law – that Mr Johnson dubbed the Surrender Bill – would force the PM to ask for a three month extension if a deal could not be done and passed through Parliament.

The deadline is October 19 to coincide with the European Council meeting.

In public, Mr Johnson hinted he would ignore the new law, vowing that the UK will leave the bloc on October 31 ‘do or die.’

He said he would rather be ‘dead in a ditch’ than have to beg for an extension and told the Tory faithful at this week’s party conference he wanted to ‘get Brexit done.’

However, in private it appears the PM and the government accept they will have to follow the Benn Act, which became law after receiving Royal Assent.

The court was told they will send a letter to the EU asking for more time and would not ‘frustrate the Act’.

Advertisement

Downing Street has refused to comment.

And to add to the confusion, Chairman of the Brexit-supporting European Research Group Steve Baker said the news coming out of the Scottish court did not mean there will be an extension.

Joanna Cherry and Jolyon Maugham have gone to court to seek legal clarification over whether Mr Johnson must seek an extension (Picture: Getty)

Jolyon Maugham QC, who brought the case in Edinburgh told Sky News: ‘What we learned today is that the prime minister has promised the court, in his own name, that he will ask for an extension under the Benn Act if the conditions are satisfied, in other words if parliament has not before 19 October agreed a withdrawal agreement.

‘He’s also promised the court that he will not frustrate the Benn Act by which is meant that he will not send two letters, one saying can I have an extension, the other saying please don’t give me one, he won’t collude with foreign governments to attempt to persuade those foreign governments to veto an extension.

‘Those are statements that he’s made to the court. The court has said that in those circumstances its contempt jurisdiction might be engaged.’

The PM is currently trying to renegotiate his predecessor Theresa May’s deal and make changes to the Irish backstop issue.

Officials in Europe say they are open to talking but so far they are ‘unconvinced’ by Mr Johnson’s new ideas.

The Prime Minister claims he has made a ‘genuine attempt to bridge the chasm’ with the European Union by making compromises.

Advertisement

But the Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said his Brexit plan ‘falls short in a number of aspects’ while Deputy Prime Minister Simon Coveney said: ‘If that is the final proposal, there will be no deal.’

The revelations in Edinburgh this afternoon give Mr Johnson just 15 days to get a deal or subject the UK to further limbo.

All 27 leaders would have to agree to an extension and they could put conditions on it, including making the delay longer than three months.

The EU referendum was held in June 2016 in which the public decided by a margin of 52% to 48% to leave the bloc.

If a deal cannot be reached soon, the earliest we would leave would be the end of January 2020.

The Court of Session is the highest court in Scotland and last month it ruled that Mr Johnson’s suspension of Parliament was unlawful.

That decision was upheld by the Supreme Court in London days later.

This is breaking and will be updated.
